Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Situation2: They strictly follow a detailed schedule of daily prayers, chanting, and offerings, ensuring nothing is skipped.
Story: I woke up early, sunlight filtering through the curtains, and glanced at my phone—messages from him, excited for our last weekend together before he leaves for months. My heart ached with the weight of time slipping away. He wanted to spend the whole day, just us, making memories to hold onto. But as I got out of bed, the familiar pull of my Hindu rituals called to me. The incense, the chanting, the offerings—each step a thread in the fabric of my faith, never missed, never rushed. My family expected me to honor every detail, especially on weekends when the rituals were longer and more elaborate. I could already hear my mother reminding me, “Nothing is more important than your dharma.” Yet, my boyfriend’s voice echoed in my mind, “Let’s make this day special, please.” I felt torn, guilt pressing from both sides. If I shortened my prayers, I’d betray my beliefs and disappoint my family. If I kept to my rituals, I’d lose precious hours with him, maybe our last for a long time. My heart pounded as I sat between my prayer mat and my phone, unable to move, caught in the impossible space between love and duty.
